summary: Apple exec said they saw search queries decline for the first time in April . Bears jumped on this news to claim that search was a dying business . There are a number of reasons to believe the Alphabet and Google search will be just fine moving forward .  $20 billion is the amount of revenue-sharing money that Apple receives from Alphabet each year for Google to be the exclusive search engine for its Safari browser . The revenue is pure margin and accounts for more than 15% of Apple's operating income .  Apple has 20 billion reasons why it would want to depict search as becoming increasingly irrelevant . Alphabet refuted Apple's claims about its search queries declining in a blog post . It said it continued to see overall search query growth, including on Apple devices and platforms .  AI chatbots are likely to eventually have a much different monetization model than search . The cost of answering AI queries is exponentially higher than providing search results . Google isn't making money from historical or curiosity-driven questions with no commercial relevance .  Paid tiers with some advertising support are likely the future model of the AI chatbot industry . However, this is likely to make AI chatbots more complementary than replace search . Google has a huge two-sided ad network that can connect advertisers to global, national, regional, or local audiences .  Search ad prices are likely to rise as advertisers will still need effective ways to reach consumers . With fewer high-traffic platforms available, advertisers will be willing to pay a premium to access that limited supply . The company is looking to use Gemini to enhance Google search with AI . Apple disclosed that searches in its devices' internet browsers had fallen for the first time ever last month . Well-known investors Josh Brown and Joe Terranova said that the news was significantly negative for Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) and GOOGL stock . Brown, who sold all of his GOOG stock last month, said that AAPL's statement is "extremely significant"  The internet search business is GOOG's "cash cow" and its "primary business," Terranova noted . A KKR & Co. debt sale shows how far Wall Street is willing to go to keep leveraged underwriting business from slipping away . Banks including Jefferies Financial Group Inc. and Citigroup extended low-fee revolving credit for KKR’s acquisition of Karo Healthcare . In exchange, KKR will allot them a part of the fee on the deal they lost to private lenders led by Apollo Global Management .  Banks are set to pocket around 40% of the 1.75% underwriting fee . The unusual arrangement hints at efforts to maintain relationships during bouts of market volatility that can win them business later .  Bank lenders extended about €175 million in undrawn facilities . What went unused is the €1.1 billion of drawn debt committed for the buyout of Swedish consumer-health company . KKR opted for a private unitranche, a blend of junior and senior debt .  KKR, HSBC and Citi declined to comment . Speculation is rising over how soon they’ll come across a similar situation similar to Karo’s .  US high-grade corporate bond sales surged this week to about $45 billion . It's the latest sign that markets are reopening after being shut for part of April amid trade wars . Even companies that will likely face pressure from global tariffs, including Apple and General Motors, tapped the market .  Citigroup is ramping up lending to private equity and private credit groups . JPMorgan Chase & Co. is set to lead about $6.5 billion in debt financing to support private equity firm 3G Capital’s purchase of footwear maker Skechers . Rite Aid Corp. filed for bankruptcy again, less than a year after completing restructuring .  WeightWatchers, known for its diet programs once endorsed by celebrities including Oprah Winfrey, files for bankruptcy . Synthego Corp. filed for bankruptcy with plans to sell itself to its main lender, an affiliate of private equity firm Perceptive Advisors . Deutsche Bank AG hired Citigroup Inc. executive Nicola Baker to expand its US private banking operations .  Toronto-Dominion Bank’s Jason Wen, head of US investment-grade credit sales and trading, will be leaving the firm in the next several months . Nomura Holdings Inc. has hired Bank of America Corp. Moritz Westhoff to head its US rates business . Gary Antenberg is joining Royal Bank of Canada from Barclays Plc to focus on insurance and alternative asset management clients Matt Maloney, a partner at Gramercy Funds Management, has left after a decade with the emerging-market focused hedge fund . Apple said tariffs will cost the company $900 million in its second quarter . The tariffs are adding significant uncertainty to the company's outlook . With that added uncertainty, investor optimism appears low .  Sales climbed 5% year over year to $95.4 billion, beating Wall Street's consensus estimate of $94.6 billion . The tech giant's earnings of $1.65 per share also outpaced the average analyst estimate . Apple reshuffled its production after President Trump slapped a 145% tariff on many imports from China .  Many management teams have pulled their guidance for the year . Some have even issued two sets of guidance based on whether or not the tariffs stay in place . Apple is struggling to forecast its results as well with Cook saying it's difficult to predict beyond June .  The volatile nature of this administration's trade policies means that having a near-to-medium-term outlook for many companies is nearly impossible . Tariffs could eventually force Apple to raise prices on its products or absorb some of the costs and weigh down its profits .  Apple investors should brace for difficult times ahead if U.S. trade negotiations fall apart . Warren Buffett's advice is about focusing on the right type of businesses . Buffett: "The best business to own is one that over an extended period can employ large amounts of incremental capital at very high rates of return"  At 94 years old, Buffett decided to retire from his longtime post as CEO of Berkshire Hathaway . At the time of the announcement, he was ranked fifth on the Forbes real-time billionaires index with a net worth of around $160 billion .  Buffett started accumulating Coca-Cola stock in 1988 . Coke is still the fourth largest holding in the portfolio, accounting for close to 9% of assets . Apple still makes up 28% of Buffett's portfolio .  Few other companies represent Buffett’s investment style better than Coke . The stock trades at a price-to-earnings ratio above 28, which is arguably justified for a stellar track record of dividend growth .

Apple is grappling with significant headwinds in China that will likely weigh on growth in the near term . The company is beginning to address these issues, driven by the absence of a foldable smartphone offering and underwhelmingAIcapabilities . Bloomberg reports suggest it is close to rolling out its Apple Intelligence AI suite in China, following delays since last October .  Apple’s China revenue fell 8% YoY in Q2 FY2025, suggesting that struggles are continuing in the new financial year as well . Failure to launch a foldable smartphone in China has cost the company market share . As a result, the company's market share fell to 15%, behind Vivo and Huawei . While total smartphone shipments in China grew just 4% in 2024, foldable phone shipments grew 27% .  There are rumors of a foldable iPhone, but Apple has yet to confirm them . As long as the company fails to cater to the surging demand for foldable smartphones in China, Apple is unlikely to reverse market share losses in the foreseeable future .  Apple is reportedly partnering with Chinese AI giants Alibaba Group Holding and Baidu to bring AI features to Chinese consumers . China does not currently allow the integration of ChatGPT and Gemini into smartphones due to perceived national security threats . Partnering with domestic AI leaders is the best way for Apple to gain traction in China as an AI-friendly smartphone manufacturer .  Apple is a well-managed business, but it does not seem to be attractive as an investment option today . On Wall Street, AAPL stock carries a Moderate Buy consensus rating based on 17 Buy, eight Hold, and four Sell ratings .  Apple is encountering headwinds in China, one of its critical markets, driven by delays in bringing a foldable smartphone to market and its slow progress in AI . While recent steps on the AI front show some promise, Apple’s market share in China will likely stay under pressure .  continued appeal of its share buybacks . Apple has expressed apprehension over the potential financial consequences of a contempt ruling in favor of Epic Games . The tech giant has warned that this ruling could lead to “substantial” financial losses . The company stated that the ruling could cost it "hundreds of millions to billions" of dollars on an annual basis .  Epic Games CEOTim Sweeneyssuggested a peace deal with Apple . He stated that Epic Games would reintroduce Fortnite to the App Store and abandon all litigation if Apple relaxed its App Store rules . On Wednesday, Sweeney stated that battling Apple over the past five years cost the company over $1 billion — but he believes it was worth it .  The reintroduction of Fortnite to the App Store could also have significant implications for the gaming industry and mobile app market . The potential financial impact on Apple underscores the gravity of the situation .

Apple may be planning to change its iPhone release schedule drastically . The change could significantly impact when you can buy your next preferred model of the iPhone . It could also provide Apple with several key advantages in an increasingly competitive smartphone landscape .  Apple will launch a new iPhone family of entry-level and premium phones in unison in the fall . Instead, Apple will move to a biannual iPhone release schedule in 2026 . You can still expect to see Apple launch the new iPhone 17 family in full this fall .  Starting in 2026, Apple will launch the premium iPhone 18 series models, including the iPhone 18 Pro and iPhone 18 Slim/Air, along with a new foldable iPhone 18 in the fall . The entry-level iPhone 18 and budget iPhone 18e won’t be released until approximately six months later, in the spring of 2027 .  Apple is facing intense competition in China, Kuo says . Many smartphone manufacturers now release phones in China in the first half of the year, this leaves Apple at a disadvantage . By moving the iPhone’s entry-level and budget “e” versions .  The strategy may also encourage consumers who want the latest iPhone to upgrade to the premium model instead of waiting another six months for the entry-level model to be released . Delaying the less expensive models by six months may compel some consumers to opt for the pricier premium ones instead, ultimately benefiting Apple’s bottom line .  Currently, Apple’s manufacturing partners around the world must bring on tens of thousands of workersevery summer to assemble iPhones for the fall launch . Bottlenecks can easily occur in the manufacturing chain if enough workers aren’t available . If Apple staggers its iPhone rollout throughout the year, Chinese manufacturers may not need to staff up at the levels traditionally required .  2025 is probably the last year that Apple will launch the full family of the newest iPhones simultaneously . The move does make a lot of sense for the company from both a marketing and financial perspective .
